description: From Middle English exercise, from Old French exercise, from Latin exercitium.

entries.meaning: (countable) Any activity designed to develop or hone a skill or ability.
examples: The teacher told us that the next exercise is to write an essay.

entries.meaning: (countable, uncountable) Activity intended to improve physical, or sometimes mental, strength and fitness.
examples: I like to do my exercises every morning before breakfast.
I do crosswords for mental exercise.

entries.meaning: A setting in action or practicing; employment in the proper mode of activity; exertion; application; use.
examples: The law guarantees us the free exercise of our rights.

entries.meaning: The performance of an office, ceremony, or duty.
examples: I assisted the ailing vicar in the exercise of his parish duties.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) That which gives practice; a trial; a test.

verbs.description: exercise (third-person singular simple present exercises, present participle exercising, simple past and past participle exercised)

entries.meaning: To exert for the sake of training or improvement; to practice in order to develop.
examples: to exercise troops or horses;â€ƒ to exercise one's brain with a puzzle

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To perform physical activity for health or training.
examples: I exercise at the gym every day.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To use (a right, an option, etc.); to put into practice.
examples: The tenant exercised his option to renew the tenancy.
She is going to exercise her right to vote.

entries.meaning: (now often in passive) To occupy the attention and effort of; to task; to tax, especially in a painful or vexatious manner; harass; to vex; to worry or make anxious.
(obsolete) To set in action; to cause to act, move, or make exertion; to give employment to.
